name: Survival / Playuela
notes: Cliff-backed cove reached by trail from Surfer’s/Crash Boat area; strong rip on swells; no services. (OSM/Mapcarta; Google)

name: Wilderness
notes: Open coast reef break; exposed and powerful in winter; no facilities. (OSM; Google; local surf guides)

name: Surfer’s Beach
notes: Consistent reef peaks; sharp rock/urchins; advanced when sizable. (OSM; Google; surf maps)

name: Gas Chambers
notes: Heavy, hollow right on big N/NW swells; for experts; shallow reef. (OSM; Google; surf guides)

name: Peña Blanca (Wishing Well)
notes: Small cove with clear days in summer; narrow sand; watch shorebreak. (Mapcarta/OSM; Google)

name: Borinquen Beach
notes: Long open stretch west of the airport; intermittent rocky areas. (OSM; Google)

name: Martinica Beach
notes: Town-side strand near Rompeolas; modest surf; casual vibe. (OSM; Google)

name: Rompeolas / Muelle Viejo
notes: Breakwater/harborfront area with small pocket sands; urban amenities. (OSM; Google)

name: Colón Beach
notes: Compact town beach just south of Rompeolas; calm most days. (OSM; Google)

name: Crash Boat South (Almirante Beach)
notes: Quieter edge of Crash Boat with easier entry on calm days. (OSM; Google)

name: Jobos Beach
notes: Lively bay with surf on the outer reef; inside cove calmer on small days. (OSM; Google; DRNA)

name: Montones Beach
notes: Natural rock pools form a calm lagoon when low to mid tide. (OSM; Google; local guides)

name: Shacks (Bajuras)
notes: Reef channels and blue holes; strong currents possible; kites on trades. (Mapcarta; Google)

name: Pozo Teodoro
notes: Shallow protected pool area; best at low tide; no lifeguards. (OSM; Google)

name: Middles
notes: Contest-quality A-frames on larger winter swells; strong rips. (Surf maps; Google; OSM)

name: Villa Pesquera (Isabela)
notes: Fishermen’s area with pocket sands and eateries; modest surf. (OSM; Google)

name: Pastillo Beach
notes: Dramatic cliffs/caves (Golondrinas nearby); strong shorebreak and currents. (Mapcarta; Google)

name: Cueva de las Golondrinas Cove
notes: Seasonal sea cave; check tides/swell; no services. (OSM; Google; travel blogs)

name: Aguada Town Beach
notes: Casual strand lining the PR-115 waterfront; low-key vibe. (OSM; Google)

name: Aguada Malecón Strip
notes: Waterfront promenade with pocket sands and eateries. (OSM; Google)

name: Buyé Beach
notes: Shaded, calm cove with turquoise water; popular on weekends. (OSM; Google; DPR tourism)

name: Balneario de Boquerón
notes: Wide arc of sand with facilities; festive town scene nearby. (DRNA; Blue Flag; Google)

name: Combate Beach
notes: Long golden strand south of Boquerón; shallow entry; popular. (OSM; Google; DPR)

name: La Playuela (Playa Sucia)

name: Joyuda Strip Beaches

name: Isla de Ratones (Cayo Ratones)
notes: Small islet off Joyuda; boat/water taxi only; clear water on calm days. (OSM; Google; local tours)

name: Punta Arenas (Puerto Real side)
notes: Working harbor shoreline with sandy pockets; low-key. (OSM; Google)

name: Playita Rosada
notes: Famed sea-pool platform with pink boardwalk; tidal; check maintenance hours. (OSM; Google; municipal)

name: Cayo Caracoles Sandbar

name: Mata La Gata
notes: Mangrove islet with swimming area and picnic shelters. (OSM; Google; tours)

name: Cayo Enrique

name: La Parguera Waterfront

name: Playa Oeste

name: Parque del Litoral Shore

name: El Maní Beach

name: Ardilla (north pocket)

name: Cerro Gordo Shore (north aerostat)

notes: Long breakwater with snorkel entries on calm days; no lifeguards. (DiscoverPR)

name: Esperanza Beach (Malecón)
notes: Townfront strand along malecón; launch for tours; small sandy entries. (ViequesBeachMap)

name: Sea Glass Beach (Vieques)
notes: Small urban strand known for sea glass; swim quality varies. (ViequesBeachMap)

name: Starfish Beach (Vieques)
notes: Shallow sandy pocket near Punta Arenas with starfish habitat; look, don’t touch. (ViequesBeachMap)

name: Airport Beach (Vieques)
notes: Townside stretch near aerodrome; small sandy entries; not guarded. (ViequesBeachMap)

name: La Plata / Platita
notes: Clear cove(s) east of Pata Prieta; reefy; unguarded. (ViequesBeachMap)

name: La Chata (Vieques)
notes: Small town pocket near Isabel II; shore fishing/sea glass. (ViequesBeachMap)

name: Playa Grande (Vieques)
notes: Long open‑coast strand on south‑west; exposed; turtle nesting area. (ViequesBeachMap)

name: Punta Galíndez (townfront)
notes: Point by Isabel II with small sandy/bathy entries; views to mainland. (ViequesBeachMap)

name: Playa Vieja (Vieques)
notes: Sector beach west of Isabel II; calm on small days; few services. (ViequesBeachMap)

name: Boca Quebrada (Vieques)
notes: Small sector near Sun Bay; sandy pockets; unguarded. (ViequesBeachMap)

name: Cayo Aurora (Gilligan’s Island)
notes: Mangrove cay with shallow channels; kayak/boat shuttle only. (DiscoverPR; PRDayTrips)

name: Playa Ballena (Guánica)
notes: Inside Dry Forest reserve at end of PR‑333; ~30‑min walk; pristine. (DiscoverPR; PRDayTrips)

name: Playa Manglillo (Guánica)
notes: Shallow bay with mangrove trails and secluded spots. (DiscoverPR)

name: Playa Jaboncillo (Guánica)
notes: Small bay near Guánica Harbor entrance; calm on most days. (TripAdvisor)

name: Domes Beach
notes: Point break by the old nuclear dome; strong winter swell; not ideal for beginners.

name: María’s Beach
notes: Classic surf spot with reef bottom; active scene; strong rip currents when pumping.

name: Sandy Beach
notes: Long sandy stretch with hotels/bars; shorebreak can be heavy at times.

name: Steps Beach (Tres Palmas)
notes: Protected reef; crystal visibility on calm days; advanced surf on big swells.

name: Pools Beach
notes: Small natural pools at lower tide; watch for rocks and sea urchins.

name: Little Malibu
notes: Inside the town plaza coastline; mellow rights on smaller swells.

name: Dogman’s Beach
notes: Reefy lineup between María’s and Domes; powerful on winter swells.

name: Spanish Wall Beach
notes: Reach by trail from Domes/Railway path; dramatic cliff backdrop; no services.

name: Corcega Beach
notes: Smoother water on many days; popular for families and paddle craft.

name: Barrero/Los Almendros
notes: Shady almond trees; generally smaller surf; watch for rocky patches.

name: Pico de Piedra
notes: Town balneario with facilities and summer festivals; gentler water most days.

name: Espinar Beach
notes: Relaxed local stretch; intermittent rocks; low-key vibe.

name: Crash Boat Beach
notes: Famous pier and turquoise water; lively on weekends; jumps are popular.
